title.native: ＣＬＡＮＮＡＤ ~After Story~ クラナド アフターストーリー

description:
A few months have passed since Tomoya declared his love to Nagisa, and his life keeps moving forward as he continues to meet a variety of new people, expanding his world in the process. While Tomoya's world continues to expand, his and Nagisa's relationship is entering a new phase, and neither of them is quite sure where it will take them. Through his relationship with Nagisa, Tomoya begins to understand the meaning and importance of family.

But as Tomoya and Nagisa begin a family of their own, they are faced with many hardships along the way in Clannad: After Story

(Source: Sentai Filmworks, edited)

Note: Includes 2 un-numbered 'extra' and 'summary' episodes that aired at the end of the series.

node.description:
Key is a Japanese visual novel studio. It is known for making dramatic and plot-oriented visual novels. Some of their most famous works include CLANNAD, planetarian, and Little Busters!, among others. Several of their visual novels have received anime adaptations, making them quite well-known even outside of the visual novel community.

They've also formed Key Sounds Label for their music tracks, and they produced an Internet radio show called Key Net Radio which is now defunct as of 2010. Key works under the publishing company Visual Arts, where it originally sprung out of.

__Graduated:__ Chuukyou University (Department of Psychology)

__Introduction:__
Jun Maeda is a Japanese scriptwriter, lyricist, composer and music producer. He is known as one of the founding members of the software company Key, and he is the main composer and original creator for most of Key's visual novels. His most notable works are Kanon (Mai and Makoto routes), Air, Clannad, Angel Beats!, Tomoyo After, and Little Busters!. Maeda also worked on Summer Pockets, which he claimed "needed to make readers cry or it would mean the end for Key".

__Biography:__
Before forming Key, Maeda worked for the company Tactics where he had a hand in the creation of two games for that company: Moon and One: Kagayaku Kisetsu e.
[Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/kay_comment)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/hinoueitaru) | [Website](https://hinoueitaru.com/)
Artist for various bishoujo games, mainly Key.

A prominent director and a key member of [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/).

After graduating from Osaka Designers' College in the late '80s, Ishihara joined Kyoto Animation and began his career as an animator. In 1991, he made his debut as a director with [Shiawasette Naani](https://anilist.co/anime/13441/). After that, he switched his focus to directing. Back then Kyoto Animation was still a sub-contracting studio, so therefore Ishihara could only get a handful of opportunities directing. Some of the shows in which Ishihara got to direct multiple episodes were [Tenchi Muyou!](https://anilist.co/anime/696/), [Aka-chan to Boku](https://anilist.co/anime/1485/), [Hyper Police](https://anilist.co/anime/1180/), and [Inuyasha](https://anilist.co/anime/249/). He also storyboarded the majority of the episodes he directed.

In 2003, Kyoto Animation started their transformation into a full-fledged animation studio producing their first anime series, [Fullmetal Panic? Fumoffu](https://anilist.co/anime/72/). Ishihara directed and storyboarded the 7th episode of the show. Two years later in 2005, he made his proper directorial debut directing the studio's second TV show, [Air](https://anilist.co/anime/101/). The following year he directed the award winning anime series, [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/). From here Ishihara has gone on to direct multiple of Kyoto Animation's acclaimed works.
__Naohiro Tafu__ is a Japanese producer and animation planner. He currently works for the company Movic.
Began as a painter at Mushi Production then left and established Kyoto Animation with her husband [Hideaki Hatta](https://anilist.co/staff/107789/Hideaki-Hatta).
Shinichi Nakamura is a producer working for Pony Canyon.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/志茂文彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fumihiko_Shimo)

Noted for writing the scripts for Kyoto Animation's anime adaptations of Key visual novels.

Began his career as a production assistant on [Grave of the Fireflies](https://anilist.co/anime/578/), but switched to writing right after.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/志茂文彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fumihiko_Shimo)

Noted for writing the scripts for Kyoto Animation's anime adaptations of Key visual novels.

Began his career as a production assistant on [Grave of the Fireflies](https://anilist.co/anime/578/), but switched to writing right after.

[Twitter](https://x.com/togoshimagome?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor)

He was composed music for Key (1999-2006) and other VisualArt's branches. 
His works include contributions to the soundtracks of Air, Clannad, Planetarian, Little Busters, Tomoyo After, Fairchild, 5, Sakura no Ki Shita de, Oshikake Princess, Maiden Halo, and Alma: Zutto Soba ni.
Musical composer, widely known for his work in Air TV, Kanon, Clannad, Little Busters, and other Key pieces.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

__Graduated:__ Chuukyou University (Department of Psychology)

__Introduction:__
Jun Maeda is a Japanese scriptwriter, lyricist, composer and music producer. He is known as one of the founding members of the software company Key, and he is the main composer and original creator for most of Key's visual novels. His most notable works are Kanon (Mai and Makoto routes), Air, Clannad, Angel Beats!, Tomoyo After, and Little Busters!. Maeda also worked on Summer Pockets, which he claimed "needed to make readers cry or it would mean the end for Key".

__Biography:__
Before forming Key, Maeda worked for the company Tactics where he had a hand in the creation of two games for that company: Moon and One: Kagayaku Kisetsu e.

name.native: アナン ギャルド アイズ

node.description: ANANT-GARDE EYES is a Japanese music unit mostly known for their work on the soundtrack for Angel Beats!.  They often work with the singer Lia, having arranged many of her songs.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/池田和美)

Kazumi Ikeda is a Japanese animator and character designer currently affiliated with [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/). She joined KyoAni in 1995 after graduating from Yoyogi Animation Gakuin and transferred to the studio's Osaka branch [Animation Do](https://anilist.co/studio/929/Animation-Do) when it was established in 2000.

She is best known for doing the character designs in KyoAni's anime adaptations of Key's most prominent visual novels, [Kanon](https://anilist.co/anime/1530/Kanon-2006/) and [Clannad](https://anilist.co/anime/2167/Clannad/), marking also her debut as chief animation director on the Kanon remake.

She has no blood relationship with late [Shouko Ikeda](https://anilist.co/staff/102736/).

[Official Website](https://lia-music.jp/) | [Twitter](https://x.com/Liabobo3) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/lia_vocalist/?hl=en)

She is affiliated with the group, Veil.  Sampling voice for Vocaloid, [IA](https://anilist.co/staff/124349/IA)

[Website](http://chanekino.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/chanekino) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chata) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/茶太)

A Japanese singer who has performed theme songs for games and anime. She has also participated in various doujin music circles. Her own private circle is called Usagi Kinoko.

__Graduated:__ Chuukyou University (Department of Psychology)

Japanese progressive rock music group which debuted on October 11, 2003.
